sources.title: Convicts Code
sources.description: On parole after three years in prison, a football player (Robert Kent) encounters the man (Sidney Blackmer) who framed him. Watch on RetroFlix:¬† https://retroflix.org/convicts-code-1939/

sources.title: Convicts Code
sources.description: An ex-con is employed by the man who framed him for bank robbery. You can find more information regarding this film on its IMDb page .

sources.title: Convict's Code (1939) [Drama] [Crime]
sources.description:
Convict's Code is a 1939 American film directed by Lambert Hillyer. The movie (also known as "Paroled to Exile") is about a man, who's framed and sent to prison for a crime he didn't commit. When he is let out on limited parole, he sets out to clear his honor and find the real criminals.

---

Directed by Lambert Hillyer, produced by E.B. Derr and Frank Melford, written by John W. Krafft, starring Robert Kent as Dave Tyler, Anne Nagel as Julie Warren, Sidney Blackmer as Gregory Warren, Victor Kilian as Bennett, Norman Willis as Russell, Maude Eburne as Mrs. Magruder, Ben Alexander as Jeff Palmer, Pat Flaherty as Sniffy, Carleton Young as Pete Jennings, Howard C. Hickman as Warden, Joan Barclay as Elaine and Harry Strang as Tom Lynch.

---

Source: "Convict's Code" Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc.. 6 October 2012. Web. 29 May 2013. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convict%27s_Code.

If you like this movie and our channel, please subscribe: https://goo.gl/0qDmXe

sources.title: Convict‚Äôs Code (1939) | Colorized Public Domain Crime Drama Classic with Robert Kent & Anne Nage
sources.description:
Convict‚Äôs Code (1939) is an American crime drama directed by Lambert Hillyer, a prolific filmmaker known for his work in early Hollywood spanning silent films, B-movies, and Westerns. Produced and distributed by Monogram Pictures, one of the famed ‚ÄúPoverty Row‚Äù studios of the era, this fast-paced and gritty picture explores crime, justice, loyalty, and redemption. Now fully restored and colorized by Colorized Public Domain, this film takes on new life for today‚Äôs audiences in the United States, Europe, and beyond, offering a vivid reintroduction to a little-known gem from Hollywood‚Äôs Golden Age.

Plot Summary:
Robert Kent stars as Dave Tyler, a promising college football star whose life is derailed when he is wrongly convicted of embezzlement. Sent to prison for a crime he did not commit, Tyler loses not only his freedom but also his reputation, his athletic career, and the trust of those closest to him. Upon his release, he faces the daunting challenge of rebuilding his life in a society that distrusts former convicts.

Determined to clear his name, Tyler takes a job at a construction company run by the sympathetic Warren Richards (Sidney Blackmer). There, he meets Richards‚Äô daughter, Jerry Richards (Anne Nagel), who slowly grows to believe in his innocence. But as Tyler attempts to live an honest life, his past continues to haunt him. Ruthless gangsters, corrupt business associates, and lingering suspicions threaten to drag him back into trouble.

With the aid of Jerry‚Äôs faith and his own determination, Tyler uncovers the real culprits behind the crime that destroyed his life. His journey becomes not just a fight for personal redemption but also a powerful statement about truth, resilience, and justice in an unforgiving world.

Cast and Crew:
‚Ä¢ Director: Lambert Hillyer
‚Ä¢ Writer: Charles Williams (screenplay), based on a story by Norton S. Parker
‚Ä¢ Cinematography: Arthur Martinelli
‚Ä¢ Production: Monogram Pictures

Starring:
‚Ä¢ Robert Kent as Dave Tyler
‚Ä¢ Anne Nagel as Jerry Richards
‚Ä¢ Sidney Blackmer as Warren Richards
‚Ä¢ Victor Kilian as Jenkins
‚Ä¢ Wade Boteler as Coach ‚ÄúPop‚Äù Hanson
‚Ä¢ Pat Flaherty as Joe Kelly
‚Ä¢ Dewey Robinson as Mike

Film Significance:
Convict‚Äôs Code (1939) captures the raw energy of B-movie crime dramas at the tail end of the 1930s. While produced on a modest budget, the film reflects the social anxieties of its time ‚Äî issues of corruption, second chances, and the stigma faced by ex-convicts in Depression-era America. Its themes of wrongful conviction and the struggle for redemption echo throughout classic Hollywood cinema, making it a notable entry in the crime-drama genre.

Anne Nagel, known for her appearances in films like Black Friday (1940) and several serials, brings depth to her role as the loyal and compassionate Jerry Richards. Robert Kent delivers a strong leading performance as the embattled hero, balancing toughness with vulnerability. Sidney Blackmer, later famed for his role in Rosemary‚Äôs Baby (1968), lends gravitas to the story. Director Lambert Hillyer, whose career spanned nearly 50 years, gives the film a tight pace and efficient storytelling style that were hallmarks of Monogram Pictures productions.

Enhanced Public Domain Explanation:
Convict‚Äôs Code is in the public domain, allowing it to be freely shared, preserved, and studied without copyright restriction. Colorized Public Domain revitalizes this rare gem through digital restoration, enhanced sound, and careful colorization. By doing so, we introduce new audiences to a film that might otherwise remain forgotten in dusty archives. Our mission is to preserve film history while making it vibrant and accessible to viewers across the USA, Europe, and worldwide.

Why Watch This Colorized Edition:
Originally released in black and white, Convict‚Äôs Code was a product of Monogram‚Äôs B-movie crime cycle. While its original monochrome version carries historical authenticity, colorization breathes new energy into the visuals ‚Äî from the gritty prison sequences to the hopeful moments of redemption, the bustling city streets, and the emotional close-ups of its actors. This enhanced edition highlights details that enrich the storytelling, ensuring modern audiences can connect with the film on a deeper level.

Colorized Public Domain specializes in restoring and colorizing timeless films across genres ‚Äî from crime dramas to comedies, thrillers, Westerns, and Golden Age Hollywood rarities. Our uploads are designed to preserve film history while appealing to modern tastes, ensuring these cultural treasures remain accessible for generations.

PizzaFLIX Presents CLASSIC MOVIE MONDAY

Director: Lambert Hillyer
üçï NEW HD RESTORATIONüçï
This hard-hitting 1939 crime drama from Monogram Pictures, directed by Lambert Hillyer, dives deep into a world of corruption, false accusations, and one man‚Äôs fight to reclaim his life. Starring Robert Kent as a wrongfully convicted ex-athlete, the story follows his release from prison and his determined search to expose the real criminal who set him up.

Anne Nagel co-stars as the loyal and resourceful woman who stands by his side, offering both emotional support and fearless determination. With supporting performances by Sidney Blackmer and Victor Kilian, the film dives deep into themes of justice, betrayal, and redemption. Known for its taut storytelling and low-budget efficiency, the film showcases the no-nonsense style of Monogram Pictures‚Äîa studio famed for delivering compelling crime stories during Hollywood‚Äôs Poverty Row era.
